narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-10, if you wish
comments: I gave the class an average-poor rating because the course did not go deep academically or theoretically into the issues. The usefulness of this rating comes down to your belief about the usefulness of practitioner-leaning courses. I did enjoy the wonderful array of guest speakers, but I am a person who thinks the best instruction for later practice is academically challenging instruction rooted in theory and creativity. I was surprised at my ability to use the language of the course well in the final project though, so there is use in that.

Unfortunately, there was not much substance to the course. I wish there had been more practically applicable information rather than general topics like "eco-efficiency" and a case study or two that focused too much on upper, upper management decisions. Maybe there is not enough substance for this class to be a full-semester class. Green to Gold itself is very much an outline. Using that as a jumping off point for more depth would have been better than more or less covering the material in the book in class.
Excellent course, excellent mixture of theory and case studies. The professors were great.
This class is a vital first step to exploring corporate environmental strategy.

The course was most valuable when Steve Ramsey or guest speakers lectured and less so during Professor Esty's presentations. Although I am a believer in the tenants of eco-strategic advantage, I need more empirical evidence to be convinced of its success than Professor Esty's content afforded. Conversely, Steve Ramsey was incredibly effective at framing issues and strategies.
4. Steve Ramsey far superior to Dan Esty in engaging with students and delivering lectures. Prof. Esty was perfunctory at best and disengaged at worst.

Q5&7 The instructors encouraged student participation during the class but then did not participate in the one significant activity that required student presentations. The latter caused a fair amount of grumbling from students.
Business management oriented, but still relevant to non business degree students

Questions 7 and 10. Although the teachers seem capable, the material being taught is useless. Using the prefix 'Eco' in front of regular business words is not Environmental Management and doesn't provide a Strategic Advantage no matter how nice it sounds on Green to Gold. The teachers showed disrespect by not showing to student presentations, taping them instead, and submitting grades for them 8 weeks later. The assignments had little to do with course work. Important classes (such as two on CSR) were skipped in favor of "guest lecturers" that showed up and told us nice stories, presentations and anecdotes but taught us little to do with the actual class. I will strongly discourage anyone from taking this class.
5. I didn't actually contact the professor outside of class.
-overall really useful case studies in the class-great introduction of various sustainability tools
Save yourself a semester and read 'Green to Gold.' That's all this course amounts to.
BP presentations
I enjoyed the classes with lively discussions the most -- the RAN/Citi case was great and I wish we could have done more of that throughout the semester
The final project. A good way to synthesize the material
The case studies and the experiences of the Professors.
The experience of writing a sustainability strategy from the perspective of a chief sustainability officer.
Steve Ramsey's course management and lectures.

1. Guest speakers were engaging and knowledgable.2. Steve Ramsey's lectures were extremely interesting. He provided actionable suggestions on addressing environmental management and strategic issues and was open and honest with his own opinions about the various case studies.

For the willing student, this class provided a good opportunity to think of important business&environmental issues from a perspective that perhaps they hadn't had to or cared to previously.Also the great line-up of guest speakers added a lot to the class.
The real world examples of corporate strategies and analysis.
New Ideas for capitalism
The lectures offered a lot of great information.
-the lectures were fast-paced and generally informative.

The course provided an excellent introduction to the intersection of business and conservation/sustainability. Prof Esty gave a broad survey of what is going on with corporations and sustainability and various strategies they are taking to be green. The information used was very current which made it interesting and relevant.

Professor Ramsey was a fantastic lecturer. He engaged the students in the material by asking questions and drawing from his own extensive professional experience. I really enjoyed learning from him.Also I found all the visiting speakers to be a hugely important component of the course. I was very impressed with their professional backgrounds, speaking skills, and thoughts on the material taught in this course.Finally, I really enjoyed the BP project.
The final project was the sole aspect of this class that I found at all useful or appropriate. In particular, the final will give you a writing sample to show to potential employers.
The Professors and lecturers invited have a lot of experience in the real world, and that matters a lot!
insights of the professors

narratives.question_text: The things about this course most in need of improvement are:
comments: NA
More discussion and deeper dives into case studies

The lectures need to go deeper into the theory behind sustainability and environmental progress through business. What is the roll of business? We answered this question through examples, but we did not dive into the philosophy and rich theory behind this question.

Steve Ramsey's part was too GE-heavy. I know that's his frame of reference, but it played like a giant case study and was hard to get perspective. Esty should have gone into more depth rather than the outline form that he seemed to stick to.

It will be nice to have more strategy based training based on reading. Reading materials were good but too bad we didn't get to utilize them.Regarding guest lecturers, it was nice to have them but there has to be some linkage between the course. And sometimes there was no announcement before the guest lecture so I had to listen to lectures without being prepared.It would be better to have guest lectures aligned with scheduled course materials. (For example, Ben&Jerry talk was great but we didn't touch anything at all about green marketing at the talk but that was originally scheduled in the syllabus).

Adding more data analysis to the course to explore how environmental strategy can truly be value-adding; Re-thinking the assignments of the course - I would have preferred to write a sustainability report earlier in the semester and then do the group presentation farther into the class.
Some form of 3rd formal assignment to pace the course better, rather than mere discussion. Another short paper, perhaps.

1. Prof. Esty's lectures were dry, boring, and repeated information already available in his book. He rarely engaged with the class and failed to attend key assignments and class sessions such as the BP presentations.

The instructors clearly know their material as well as one could hope for; sometimes this comfort may have allowed them to be less structured in their agenda, so we would end up reiterating much of what was assigned in the reading rather than digging deeper.
Content should be more practical instead of anecdotal.

When the professors asked questions, it seemed that they required a canned response without room for discussion about new ideas and/or concepts.While our final project required us to develop a sustainability plan, I would have liked to learn more about developing it with concrete examples or templates. I'm not sure if we will get any feedback on our submitted paper and it would be helpful to know if we completed it effectively.
-move away from some redundant or overlapping topics; supplement the course discussions with newer case studies-move away from group assignments (see below)

Professor Esty could use PowerPoint to liven up the lectures. It would also be helpful to have some smaller assignments throughout the semester. I would have really liked to have written brief sustainability strategies earlier on to get a better idea of how to write them. By writing an additional paper during the course I would have learned the material in greater depth.
Professor Esty is so thoughtful and smart, but I wished he could have engaged the students a bit more during his lectures.

In five years of taking university courses, I have never met a professor less engaged with students and his role as course instructor. It is abundantly clear that he has at least 4 other priorities that outrank his teaching. This went from being frustrating, to just a class-wide running joke. He only lectured at 1/4 of the time, leaving the brunt of the work to guest speakers and a co-lecturer. Neither he nor co-lecturer bothered showing up for the all-important mid-term presentation. Furthermore, I would be shocked if either lecturer actually read our final project. Grading was arbitrary to the point of being unfair.
feedback on grades

narratives.question_text: What was the availability and quality of help you received of the instructor and TA?
comments: TA - great
Great
Even though it was sometimes difficult to reach the professor, the experience and collaboration were worth it. Excellent feedback from them.
TA gave me guidance on the structure of my final strategy paper.
They were very responsive to emails.
1. Stuart DeCew was extremely efficient and responsive as TA and Steve Ramsey was always helpful and supportive in addressing any issues.

I found that the lead instructors office hours were very difficult to make work as they were always changing. The other lead instructor was not available the one time I attempted to meet but that may not be indicative of his overall availability. The TA seemed to be the main point of contact for the class and was typically responsive.
Instructor and TA have been very helpful in answering my questions.

The TA was very helpful in getting us connected to professionals and was very prompt in answering our questions.I had some good conversations with Steve Ramsey following our class. He seemed very approachable and interested in engaging us further in this work.
-TA often failed to post readings-some responses from TA re: assignment were helpful; did not seem like TA grasped what professors wanted at times
Stuart was great and responded to all of my email inquiries.
Professor Ramsey was very helpful outside of the classroom, as was Stuart. I never interacted with Professor Esty.

The professor changes his office hours every week. The usual claim is 'scheduling conflicts,' but I'm pretty sure he does it to simply avoid meeting with students. Even if scheduling conflicts are legitimate, it is yet another example of how low 'teaching' ranks on his list of priorities.
great

narratives.question_text: Discuss if you wish how this course fits into your overall program.
comments: It is a course perfectly designed for the Masters of Environmental Management since it provides the corporate and business perspective of the environmental management.
This course is a strong foundation to exploring corporate sustainability efforts further down the line.
I am pursuing a course of study in strategy and social&environmental enterprise.
I found it to work very well in tandem with Greening Business Operations - this as a high-level strategy component that teaches students how executives approach sustainability.
It should relate to my CSR interests, however as the instructor decided to skip that class so we could hear from a guy at walmart and Jerry from ben&jerry's I guess I'll have to buy a book instead.
-good overview on topics of sustainability in the corporate world- a very unique class!

This course was an excelled introduction for me. I was eager to learn about business and the environment and this course served as a perfect introduction and survey course. I plan to take further courses on the topics of business and the environment.

Subject matter is interesting and useful, especially for those interested in business. And the workload is particularly light. But considering the arbitrary grading, I wish I would've savedmyself the semester and just read the book.
great view of the corporate approach to environmental issues.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: Wanted to learn more about environmental management
Interst in the intersection of business and the environment -- very skeptical of "CSR"
To understand the business case for being environmentally friendly.
Because I knew the textbook previously and I am very interested in learning and applying environmental strategies applied to corporations and companies. Excellent for CSR.
I took this course to learn various aspects of environmental management.
To understand the frameworks to consider corporate environmental management.
See 15.
See how environmental issues dovetailed into strategic issues in a business context.
I aim to be an environmental sustainability coordinator or consultant and wanted to learn what businesses are doing and how to find opportunities to do more in that arena.
It's related to my academic interest and I like the two instructors.
Integrating business motivations into environmental policy
To learn the business perspective on environmental management and CSR.
I actually wanted to learn more about ecolabeling and certification practices.
- to learn about how to integrate environmental techniques into the corporate world

I took this course to learn about the intersection of business and the environment and to learn what was going on beneath the green washing, recent spikes in business sustainability acts, and so on. I was also interested in exploring the field of sustainability consulting for businesses.
Subject matter is promising and very related to my interests.
fits with my interests

narratives.question_text: Did it live up to your expectations?
comments: Yes
Yes
No. I don't think I learned many more arguments than the obvious ones that I knew coming in. Maybe that's just the problem with corporate environmental strategy, in general and not the class.
Yes, totally!
At some point yes, but not quite in terms of practical knowledge.
The subject matter did, but I would have liked a greater level of analysis, especially when looking at corporate sustainability efforts.
Yes
No.
Yes
Yes.
Yes; full of ideas
It fell far below.

The class covered a lot of material that I wasn't familiar with in my previous career. I found it very interesting and would have like to delve deeper into some of theareas. Overall, the class offered an overview of various aspects about the ways environmental initiatives are intertwined into the business sphere.
-generally.
Yes.
No, just a poorly-run course. Pretty disappointing.
yes

narratives.question_text: Did you get out of it what you expected?
comments: Yes
Yes
Of course, the course covered the most important issues of corporate environmental strategies and the professor's views and experiences were fundamental.
Echoing my above comment, I would have liked greater depth of analysis. Less breadth.
Yes
Not really.
Yes - though perhaps a few more small exercises would be warranted, as I found the few we did to be interesting&useful.
Yes.
Yes, a better understanding of the business outlook on environmental performance
Not at all.
It covered the concepts a bit more superficially than I expected, but I found it very interesting.

-almost. i learned about a few interesting case studies. some more detail couldhave been used in areas, get more into specifics so that we can actually apply them in the real world and into a variety of settings.
Yes, only I expected to receive a bit more depth and to learn how to write a variety of different sustainability strategies throughout the semester.
No, but the final project - despite being given very little guidance on it - was a valuable exercise.
yes

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Advantage: Learning from classmates, sharing workloadDisadvantage: Scheduling, differing viewpoints, unequal amount of work done
Everything was great. Very good experiences
For the BP assignment, it almost felt like the group size was too big for the scope of the assignment

The SOM communications practice was great. Although my group did fine on the grade for the group work, others did not do so fine. I think there grade was unfair because the instructor did not ask for a specific outcome, but graded specifically. Also, there were many levels of advice, including the SOM communications guidance, which for some people actually contradicted with what the graders were looking for. The group BP project was fun and engaging, but the instructions need to match the grading.
Got to know new people and it is always good practice to work in groups.
Excellent opportunity to work in teams and apply professional techniques in quite a complex issue.
Good to get to know classmates and learn from them. I learn a lot by preparing group presentation material and practicing the actual presentation.

Group work was great experience. The experience could have been more valuable if we had more guidance on group strategy and longer process of putting together the materials, practicing presenting, and then performing.

Interesting to work with students from different backgrounds and perspectives on the assignment, and overall we worked quite well together.However, some members were definitely more committed to the assignment than others and inevitably bore the majority of the workload.

We had to balance the sometimes strong views/opinions of members with different professional backgrounds&ideologies to come to a common ground from which we would approach an issue. This is always good practice and for some it was obviously needed. For all involved I think it offers practical applications.
Increases the motivation to perform
It required specific knowledge that was exclusive to some members of the group and so, some of us were graded based on the ability of other members.

Advantages: Learning new information from colleagues. It was helpful to meet with the business school regarding presentation planning and delivery. I would like to see FES take more initiative to assist students in similar prep-work opportunities.Disadvantages: Lack of time for meeting. Little time to prepare.

-not many advantages. group work was a major part of our grade, groups were randomly assigned, we were graded by non-professors who were rather arbitrary.-very short lead time and unclear instructions on the group assignment.

I found it incredibly valuable to work in a group of second year FES students. I learned a lot from them about different writing and presentation skills as well as career advice. It was also great to tackle a subject and have other student' perspectives. We came out with a great outcome and a solid presentation.

It was so timely to investigate the BP disaster in detail through this course. It was great how each team focused on a different aspect of the disaster. I really enjoyed working with my team to analyze our assigned component and put together a professional presentation.
Great team work experience in a really current topic
varying perspectives and skills were a positivecoordination was a negative

narratives.question_text: For students taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take the course! You will learn a lot.
Memorize Green to Gold

Take the course for the language, exposure to speakers, and exposure to Dan Esty, who is a great guy, and does so much for the environmental community. Do not take the course if you expect to go below the surface of the issues.
There is a very light courseload, so it could work as a fifth class.

If you are fresh graduate and you don't have work experience in private sector, it's worthwhile to take this course. But if you have worked for corporations for quite sometime, it's probably not your course.
Request more readings/financing data, etc. to get a deeper picture of company strategy.

Come to class prepared and enthusiastic because if you don't willingly participate in the discussions you will likely find it boring. Also, understand that this is taught to environmental, business, and law students, so some topics might be redundant to you while material that is 'new' to you is likely not for all of your classmates.
Try out newideas; the professors are very responsive.
Don't.
-sit in the front, participate.

I would advise students that this is a survey course and does not provide enormous depth on the subject of business and the environment. However, for students looking for an introduction to this subject area it is perfect and Dan Esty is at the forefront of this field. Green to Gold is an easy, interesting read with current examples of corporate sustainability strategies. Do as many of the readings as you can, as they are all interesting and relatively short. Steve Ramsey teaches some interesting classes and can be a great contact. All of the guest speakers the course has are really great and I learned a lot from them. Try to enjoy the process of writing the final paper - it's a great opportunity to put all the pieces together and learn a lot. I really enjoyed the class and learned a lot about corporate sustainability initiatives.
must be self-motivated to keep on top of all the reading.
